text:
SPEAKER 1: Let's talk
about Kenya again.

Recently, I heard that
your president, Kenyatta,
has created--

if I understand this correctly,
a new tribe designation
of all Asians or a new tribe?
SPEAKER 2: Yes.

SPEAKER 1: Can you talk
to the broader community

about the structure
of Kenyan society

and how this
designation fits in.

SPEAKER 2: You see, we
have got quite a few tribes
SPEAKER 1: In Kenya.
SPEAKER 2: In Kenya.

Like we have got in Kalenjin,
we have got several tribes.

In Kikuyu, we have
several tribes.

In Mejikandal, we
got several tribes.

So we have about
nearly 48 tribes.

So all these years, we were
saying, bubba, we are Kenyans.
Like for example, myself.

I'm the fifth generation
Muslim by the sixth generation,

and my grandson is the
seventh generation.

And some of the tribes,
which are in Kenya,
are as old as our forefathers--
came to this country.

But we are not
considered as a tribe.

We are still considering
the Indian or European
excluded from the--
SPEAKER 1: Tribal structure.
SPEAKER 2: From the indigenous.

When they say
indigenous Kenyan, we

are not considered
as indigenous Kenyan.
SPEAKER 1: I see.

SPEAKER 2: We would never
fight and say, listen, bubba,

we are more indigenous than
some of the indigenous tribes
out there.
SPEAKER 1: I see.

SPEAKER 2: So, fortunately,
president saw it.
It says very good.
This is not a new thing.

The door we are knocking since
December '63, since Kenya
got independent.

So it is being
marginalized fortunately

by the son of the former
president, the first president.
The father of the nation.
His son has now illegalized it.

Yeah, and they get
that we are Kenyan--

Asians are the Kenyan
Asians, are the tribe.
